properties.name: anchor-name
properties.appliesTo: all elements that generate a principal box

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect.

values.name: <dashed-ident>#
values.prose: If the element generates a principal box, the element is an anchor element, with a list of anchor names as specified. Each anchor name is a tree-scoped name. Otherwise, the property has no effect.

values.name: none
values.prose: No changes in anchor name scope.

values.name: all
values.prose: Specifies that all anchor names defined by this element or its descendants—​whose scope is not already limited by a descendant using anchor-scope—​to be in scope only for this element’s descendants; and limits descendants to only match anchor names to anchor elements within this subtree.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: Specifies that a matching anchor name defined by this element or its descendants—​whose scope is not already limited by a descendant using anchor-scope—​to be in scope only for this element’s descendants; and limits descendants to only match these anchor names to anchor elements within this subtree.

properties.name: inset-area
properties.appliesTo: positioned elements with a default anchor element

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect.

values.name: <inset-area>
values.prose: If the element does not have a default anchor element, or is not an absolutely-positioned element, this value has no effect. Otherwise, the property selects a region of the inset-area grid, and makes that the element’s containing block. Additionally, the normal value for the self-alignment properties behaves as either start, end, or anchor-center, depending on the positioning of the region, to give a good default alignment for the positioned element. See § 3.1.1 Resolving <inset-area>s for details on both of these effects. Also, any auto inset properties resolve to 0.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned element has a default anchor element, then it is aligned so as to center itself over the default anchor element in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned element has a default anchor element, then it is aligned so as to center itself over the default anchor element in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned element has a default anchor element, then it is aligned so as to center itself over the default anchor element in the relevant axis.

values.name: anchor-center
values.prose: The new anchor-center value makes this case extremely simple: if the positioned element has a default anchor element, then it is aligned so as to center itself over the default anchor element in the relevant axis.

values.name: always
values.prose: This property has no effect. (The element is displayed without regard for its anchors or its overflowing status.)

values.name: anchors-valid
values.prose: If any of the element’s required anchor references do not resolve to a target anchor element, the element is strongly hidden. Does misused anchor() count, like border-width: anchor(--foo)? I assume no, so we’ll need to split out the concept of invalid usage from a valid usage that fails to find an anchor. What is a required anchor reference? anchor() functions that don’t have a fallback value; the default anchor *sometimes*? Need more detail here. Any anchors are missing, or all anchors are missing? I can see use-cases for either, potentially. Do we want to make a decision here, or make it controllable somehow?

values.name: anchors-visible
values.prose: If the element does not have a default anchor element, or it has a default anchor element but the anchor element is clipped by scrolling, this element is strongly hidden. Since only the default anchor element triggers scroll-compensation, it’s really the only one that makes sense to condition this on. Right?

values.name: no-overflow
values.prose: If the element overflows its inset-modified containing block, even after applying position-try, then the element is strongly hidden.

values.name: none
values.prose: The property has no effect; the element’s position options list is empty.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: If there is a @position-try rule with the given name, its associated position option is added to the position options list. Otherwise, this value has no effect.

values.name: flip-block
values.prose: swaps the values in the block axis (between, for example, margin-block-start and margin-block-end), essentially mirroring across an inline-axis line.

values.name: flip-inline
values.prose: swaps the values in the inline axis, essentially mirroring across a block-axis line.

values.name: flip-start
values.prose: swaps the values of the start properties with each other, and the end properties with each other (between, for example, margin-block-start and margin-inline-start), essentially mirroring across a diagonal drawn from the start-start corner to the end-end corner.

values.name: <dashed-ident> || <try-tactic>
values.prose: Combines the effects of the previous two options: if there is a @position-try rule with the given name, then applies its position option to the element’s base style, transforms it according to the specified <try-tactic>, and then adds the result to the element’s position options list. Otherwise, does nothing.

values.name: normal
values.prose: Try the position options in the order specified by position-try-options.

values.name: most-width
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply a position option using that option to the element, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-height
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply a position option using that option to the element, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-block-size
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply a position option using that option to the element, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

values.name: most-inline-size
values.prose: For each entry in the position options list, apply a position option using that option to the element, and find the specified inset-modified containing block size that results from those styles. Stably sort the position options list according to this size, with the largest coming first.

atrules.name: @position-try
atrules.prose: The @position-try rule defines a position option with a given name, specifying one or more sets of positioning properties that will be applied to an element via position-try-options,

values.name: <inset-area>
values.value: [ [ left | center | right | span-left | span-right | x-start | x-end | span-x-start | span-x-end | x-self-start | x-self-end | span-x-self-start | span-x-self-end | span-all ] || [ top | center | bottom | span-top | span-bottom | y-start | y-end | span-y-start | span-y-end | y-self-start | y-self-end | span-y-self-start | span-y-self-end | span-all ] | [ block-start | center | block-end | span-block-start | span-block-end | span-all ] || [ inline-start | center | inline-end | span-inline-start | span-inline-end | span-all ] | [ self-block-start | self-block-end | span-self-block-start | span-self-block-end | span-all ] || [ self-inline-start | self-inline-end | span-self-inline-start | span-self-inline-end | span-all ] | [ start | center | end | span-start | span-end | span-all ]{1,2} | [ self-start | center | self-end | span-self-start | span-self-end | span-all ]{1,2} ]

values.name: start
values.prose: The single corresponding row or column, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying. Like in anchor(), the plain logical keywords (start, end, etc) refer to the writing mode of the element’s containing block. The x-start/etc determine their direction in the same way, but in the specified physical axis. The "self" logical keywords (self-start, x-self-end, etc) are identical, but refer to the element’s own writing mode.

values.name: end
values.prose: The single corresponding row or column, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying. Like in anchor(), the plain logical keywords (start, end, etc) refer to the writing mode of the element’s containing block. The x-start/etc determine their direction in the same way, but in the specified physical axis. The "self" logical keywords (self-start, x-self-end, etc) are identical, but refer to the element’s own writing mode.

values.name: span-start
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-end
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-top
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-bottom
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-y-start
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-y-end
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-x-start
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-x-end
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-block-start
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-block-end
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-inline-start
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-inline-end
values.prose: Two rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying: the center row/column, and the row/column corresponding to the other half of the keyword as per the single-track keywords. (For example, span-top spans the first two rows—​the center row and the top row.)

values.name: span-all
values.prose: All three rows or columns, depending on which axis this keyword is specifying.

values.name: anchor()
values.prose: An absolutely-positioned element can use the anchor() function as a value in its inset properties to refer to the position of one or more anchor elements. The anchor() function resolves to a <length>.

values.name: <dashed-ident>
values.prose: Specifies the anchor name it will look for. This name is a tree-scoped reference.

values.name: implicit
values.prose: Selects the implicit anchor element defined for the element, if possible.

values.name: inside
values.prose: Resolves to one of the anchor element’s sides, depending on which inset property it’s used in. inside refers to the same side as the inset property (attaching the element to the "inside" of the anchor), while outside refers to the opposite.

values.name: outside
values.prose: Resolves to one of the anchor element’s sides, depending on which inset property it’s used in. inside refers to the same side as the inset property (attaching the element to the "inside" of the anchor), while outside refers to the opposite.

values.name: top
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor element.

values.name: right
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor element.

values.name: bottom
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor element.

values.name: left
values.prose: Refers to the specified side of the anchor element.

values.name: start
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor element in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned element (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned element’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: end
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor element in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned element (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned element’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: self-start
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor element in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned element (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned element’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: self-end
values.prose: Refers to one of the sides of the anchor element in the same axis as the inset property it’s used in, by resolving the keyword against the writing mode of either the positioned element (for self-start and self-end) or the positioned element’s containing block (for start and end).

values.name: <percentage>
values.prose: Refers to a position a corresponding percentage between the start and end sides, with 0% being equivalent to start and 100% being equivalent to end. center is equivalent to 50%.

values.name: center
values.prose: Refers to a position a corresponding percentage between the start and end sides, with 0% being equivalent to start and 100% being equivalent to end. center is equivalent to 50%.

values.name: <anchor-side>
values.value: inside | outside | top | left | right | bottom | start | end | self-start | self-end | <percentage> | center

values.name: anchor-size()
values.prose: An absolutely-positioned element can use the anchor-size() function in its sizing properties to refer to the size of one or more anchor elements. The anchor-size() function resolves to a <length>.

values.name: width
values.prose: The physical <anchor-size> keywords (width and height) refer to the width and height, respectively, of the target anchor element. Unlike anchor(), there is no restriction on having to match axises; for example, width: anchor-size(--foo height); is valid.

values.name: height
values.prose: The physical <anchor-size> keywords (width and height) refer to the width and height, respectively, of the target anchor element. Unlike anchor(), there is no restriction on having to match axises; for example, width: anchor-size(--foo height); is valid.

values.name: block
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the element (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the element’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: inline
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the element (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the element’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: self-block
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the element (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the element’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: self-inline
values.prose: The logical <anchor-size> keywords (block, inline, self-block, and self-inline) map to one of the physical keywords according to either the writing mode of the element (for self-block and self-inline) or the writing mode of the element’s containing block (for block and inline).

values.name: <anchor-size>
values.value: width | height | block | inline | self-block | self-inline
